componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Simona Jankowski with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Garmin Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask you about your expectations into the fourth quarter in terms of shelf space with retailers compared to last year and also promotional activity that you expect from your retailer partners. And then with all the recent introductions ove
componenttext: I just wanted to ask you about your expectations into the fourth quarter in terms of shelf space with retailers compared to last year and also promotional activity that you expect from your retailer partners. And then with all the recent introductions over the last couple of quarters, was this September quarter still one where you were benefiting from net inventory additions into the channel? Or was selling and sell-through more closely aligned?

headline: Garmin Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so in terms of the first question, we believe our shelf space actually has improved over what we had last year. For instance, this year we have expanded shelf space in Best Buy stores in their top 220 stores, going from 4 feet to 8 feet with 4 feet i
componenttext: Yes, so in terms of the first question, we believe our shelf space actually has improved over what we had last year. For instance, this year we have expanded shelf space in Best Buy stores in their top 220 stores, going from 4 feet to 8 feet with 4 feet in other stores, so that was an improvement over last year. We have additional space, for instance, for Vívofit Jr. in many retailers. So in general we feel pretty good about our shelf-space situation. And retailers, we believe, are getting behind the products in terms of buyers and promotions and specials for the holidays. So we feel good about that. In terms of selling and sell-through balance, we feel like things are fairly well balanced right now. We did have some product introductions in the quarter, such as Forerunner 35 and the Vívofit Jr. But in general those were somewhat limited sell-in in Q3, and we expect additional sell-in to occur in Q4.

headline: Garmin Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brad Erickson with Pacific Crest.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brad Erickson with Pacific Crest.

headline: Garmin Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So relative to mix, can you give us a sense of what ASPs did directionally for Fitness year-over-year and sort of how significant that was contributing to this growth we're seeing?
componenttext: So relative to mix, can you give us a sense of what ASPs did directionally for Fitness year-over-year and sort of how significant that was contributing to this growth we're seeing?

headline: Garmin Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we are selling a number of products that are higher ASP, particularly in what we would call our Tracker category, although the categories are somewhat blurring in terms of the lines between them. For instance, we have the Vívoactive HR this
componenttext: Well, I think we are selling a number of products that are higher ASP, particularly in what we would call our Tracker category, although the categories are somewhat blurring in terms of the lines between them. For instance, we have the Vívoactive HR this year, which is a mid-$200 category for us, but it is generally tracked as a tracker product. And we're also doing very well in the running side with mid- to high-range devices. So that's balanced by increased volume and lower ASPs on basic trackers. But overall, we think that we've done well in those other categories.

headline: Garmin Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then geographically, can you just rank order the contributors that drove the Fitness growth that we're seeing?
componenttext: Okay. And then geographically, can you just rank order the contributors that drove the Fitness growth that we're seeing?

headline: Garmin Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're seeing growth across the globe in all major regions, so it has been particularly strong in Europe where the market is developing. It's behind in its development compared to that of, particularly, North America, and we also saw strong growth in
componenttext: Well, we're seeing growth across the globe in all major regions, so it has been particularly strong in Europe where the market is developing. It's behind in its development compared to that of, particularly, North America, and we also saw strong growth in APAC.

headline: Garmin Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Tavis McCourt with Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Tavis McCourt with Raymond James.

headline: Garmin Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, on the Aviation segment. Obviously, your commentary seems a little different than your 2 largest competitors, who seem to have some bigger struggles there. And I'm wondering -- and then also your Q4 guidance on Aviation seems to suggest more of a f
componenttext: First, on the Aviation segment. Obviously, your commentary seems a little different than your 2 largest competitors, who seem to have some bigger struggles there. And I'm wondering -- and then also your Q4 guidance on Aviation seems to suggest more of a flattish quarter year-over-year. So was there timing of shipments that positively impacted this quarter? Or better execution on ADS-B or kind of any commentary around why the higher growth rate this quarter? And then secondly if you could comment, Doug, on foreign currency, specifically the pound. Is that a big enough move yet, given your limited exposure there to impact the fourth quarter guide?

headline: Garmin Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in terms of our experience in the aviation market, I think one of the things we see is the growth in the ADS-B category.  That did go very well for us in Q3. And it had second-order effects as we sold additional products and display systems into cockpi
componenttext: So in terms of our experience in the aviation market, I think one of the things we see is the growth in the ADS-B category.  That did go very well for us in Q3. And it had second-order effects as we sold additional products and display systems into cockpits that we're getting ADS-B upgrades. So that drove a big part of the overall growth in the aviation side. In terms of Q4 and our outlook there, the market has been soft for a long time, and so we're taking somewhat of a conservative approach as we look at Q4 and just kind of wait and see how the market develops.

headline: Garmin Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And regarding the FX impact for Q3, we saw about $6 million of a revenue headwind, primarily due to the pound. So given some of the increased weakness there, we'd probably anticipate a little bit more than that going into Q4. But I should say also th
componenttext: Yes. And regarding the FX impact for Q3, we saw about $6 million of a revenue headwind, primarily due to the pound. So given some of the increased weakness there, we'd probably anticipate a little bit more than that going into Q4. But I should say also that the percentage of our business, depending upon the pound, is about 5%. So it's not a significant percentage of our business.

headline: Garmin Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And if I could ask a quick follow-up, Cliff, on the ADS-B. Those are relatively -- as a stand-alone product, relatively low ASP.  Should we think about that as lower gross margin business? But if you're able to effectively use that to cross-sell --
componenttext: Great. And if I could ask a quick follow-up, Cliff, on the ADS-B. Those are relatively -- as a stand-alone product, relatively low ASP.  Should we think about that as lower gross margin business? But if you're able to effectively use that to cross-sell -- to sell bigger retrofit systems, then it becomes a much bigger positive impact to Garmin? Is that a good way to think about it?

headline: Garmin Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We feel like the gross margin is consistent. It's in line with the overall segments, so not really a lower margin category for us.
componenttext: We feel like the gross margin is consistent. It's in line with the overall segments, so not really a lower margin category for us.

headline: Garmin Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jerry Lou with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jerry Lou with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Garmin Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first question on gross margin. If I look at a December quarter, full-year guidance implies about a 52% gross margin, down a little over 4 points sequentially. Historically, fourth quarter tends to be a little bit lower sequentially, but this year seem
componenttext: So first question on gross margin. If I look at a December quarter, full-year guidance implies about a 52% gross margin, down a little over 4 points sequentially. Historically, fourth quarter tends to be a little bit lower sequentially, but this year seems to be a bigger magnitude than the last few years. So I wanted to see what are the main reasons? Is it product mix? Do you anticipate more promotions? Anything else?

headline: Garmin Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, in terms of overall gross margin, we do see both mix and promotional activities as driving the lower gross margin. Of course, promotional activities drive the margin by product categories and then mix of categories. In terms of the sales volume, each
componenttext: Yes, in terms of overall gross margin, we do see both mix and promotional activities as driving the lower gross margin. Of course, promotional activities drive the margin by product categories and then mix of categories. In terms of the sales volume, each one drives the overall situation in mix.

headline: Garmin Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And maybe just a bigger-picture question. When you look at some of your fitness tracker competitors like Apple, recently Aetna announced they will subsidize Apple watches, and said they just hired a  new VP of Digital health. Seems like your competi
componenttext: Okay. And maybe just a bigger-picture question. When you look at some of your fitness tracker competitors like Apple, recently Aetna announced they will subsidize Apple watches, and said they just hired a  new VP of Digital health. Seems like your competitors are looking to pilot some partnerships with insurers and others in the health care industry. So I wanted to get your take on that. What's your strategy? Do you see any opportunities to get into either the health care space or to work more with employers to subsidize some of these devices?

headline: Garmin Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as we mentioned in the remarks, we are pursuing that kind of business as well. We partnered with Cerner recently. We also have partnerships with insurance companies like Manulife and others, and we also do deals with individual corporations as well.
componenttext: Well, as we mentioned in the remarks, we are pursuing that kind of business as well. We partnered with Cerner recently. We also have partnerships with insurance companies like Manulife and others, and we also do deals with individual corporations as well. So it's an opportunity we're pursuing.

headline: Garmin Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Will Power with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Will Power with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Garmin Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions. Maybe just to come back to the Fitness. You had a couple of these high-profile launches. You had the second-generation Apple watch that has GPS for the first time. I guess, I wonder, whether you've seen any impact on your runni
componenttext: Just a couple of questions. Maybe just to come back to the Fitness. You had a couple of these high-profile launches. You had the second-generation Apple watch that has GPS for the first time. I guess, I wonder, whether you've seen any impact on your running watch business since it's, at least, somewhat more of a competitor with GPS or is it still too early? And I guess likewise, with the new Fitbit devices, I wonder if you could -- any commentary around share shifts, et cetera, that you might be seeing there?

headline: Garmin Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So in terms of the recent developments with the Apple watch and GPS, as you pointed out it is still early days. But at this point we don't see any detectable impact. I think we've said in the past that our products tend to appeal to a slightly differ
componenttext: Yes. So in terms of the recent developments with the Apple watch and GPS, as you pointed out it is still early days. But at this point we don't see any detectable impact. I think we've said in the past that our products tend to appeal to a slightly different audience than the Apple watch, although there is some overlap, but generally that's true. So that's the way we see things right now, and of course we'll see how things develop. In terms of the new Fitbit launches, in terms of our market share, we feel like it's generally stable. They've released new products, of course, and they have very strong share, but ours has also remained about where it was, we think it's in the 10% range.

headline: Garmin Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just on the Auto business. It seems like we've seen a bit of an acceleration in the year-over-year declines. I guess, I wonder if you add any more color on the drivers of that? And is this somewhat of an anomaly looking at the past couple o
componenttext: Okay. And then just on the Auto business. It seems like we've seen a bit of an acceleration in the year-over-year declines. I guess, I wonder if you add any more color on the drivers of that? And is this somewhat of an anomaly looking at the past couple of quarters? Or is this 20% kind of year-over-year decline, is this perhaps a new normal?

headline: Garmin Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think we did see the softness earlier in the year. And last quarter we updated our guidance to be slightly more down than what we had previously projected. The weaknesses are primarily driven in Europe where the market has gotten softer. We thin
componenttext: Yes. So I think we did see the softness earlier in the year. And last quarter we updated our guidance to be slightly more down than what we had previously projected. The weaknesses are primarily driven in Europe where the market has gotten softer. We think for the fourth quarter that there'll be some opportunity to kind of flatten that curve a little bit with promotional activity, but it is somewhat of a wait-and-see situation.

headline: Garmin Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ben Bollin with Cleveland Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ben Bollin with Cleveland Research.

headline: Garmin Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: First item, when you look at the Fitness business, how would you characterize the organic growth of the market as a whole? And then kind of beyond your organic growth of the market, how would you say that -- what's the benefit from incremental shelf space
componenttext: First item, when you look at the Fitness business, how would you characterize the organic growth of the market as a whole? And then kind of beyond your organic growth of the market, how would you say that -- what's the benefit from incremental shelf space or stores versus kind of product refresh and expanded SKUs as you've expanded into -- deeper into that category?

headline: Garmin Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so in terms of organic growth, there's multiple categories within Fitness from the low-end trackers on up to high-end running watches, but we've seen growth in those categories on a global basis, market growth if you will, over the past year. I think
componenttext: Yes, so in terms of organic growth, there's multiple categories within Fitness from the low-end trackers on up to high-end running watches, but we've seen growth in those categories on a global basis, market growth if you will, over the past year. I think some markets are more mature than others, as I mentioned earlier, so the situation is probably different in Americas versus Europe versus APAC. But generally the market has been growing. In terms of benefits, I think again depends on category, but new product releases always generate excitement for sure. But at the same time, shelf space is vitally important, so we're working hard to have both good shelf-space presence in retailers as well as strong product offerings.

headline: Garmin Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: When you look at the overlap you characterize with Apple, where do you see the most overlap across your portfolio when you look at Apple? Which specific products or features do you think you have the most overlap? And then one last follow-up.
componenttext: When you look at the overlap you characterize with Apple, where do you see the most overlap across your portfolio when you look at Apple? Which specific products or features do you think you have the most overlap? And then one last follow-up.

headline: Garmin Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that's somewhat of a challenge, because if you look at our Fitness product line we have one kind of product and the features and the style that's there versus Outdoor in our fenix line, which has yet a different kind of style. But generally
componenttext: Well, I think that's somewhat of a challenge, because if you look at our Fitness product line we have one kind of product and the features and the style that's there versus Outdoor in our fenix line, which has yet a different kind of style. But generally I would say that the kind of customer that overlaps with Garmin would be those that are probably more on the entry-level side to running and activity and are looking at what kind of device they could use to enhance their performance in running and other kinds of sporting activities. So that's generally the customer profile that would be overlapping with us.

headline: Garmin Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And last item, looking at the Aviation business, there was an announcement during the quarter you're expanding your capacity. What is the company's long-term view on the ability to gain share with OEMs? And how are you thinking about the potential t
componenttext: Okay. And last item, looking at the Aviation business, there was an announcement during the quarter you're expanding your capacity. What is the company's long-term view on the ability to gain share with OEMs? And how are you thinking about the potential timing of winning more business, even in regional, commercial opportunities? And last, I apologize, last one on linearity of ADS-B, how do you think about that between now and 2020? Does it build? As we approach that, is it pretty linear between now and then? What's the right way to think about how that grows?

headline: Garmin Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so in terms of our long-term view, as highlighted by the announcement we made where we're investing in the Aviation business, absolutely, we have a strong view for the future of that business. And currently we're running at near capacity in our curre
componenttext: Yes, so in terms of our long-term view, as highlighted by the announcement we made where we're investing in the Aviation business, absolutely, we have a strong view for the future of that business. And currently we're running at near capacity in our current production facilities, and so in order to meet the anticipated demand of the future, we felt like it was the right time to invest in our facilities. In terms of opportunities to win business, I think there's just many opportunities to win business. Our G3000 and 5000 lines are very strong, and we believe that those products should appeal to a broad range of business jet platforms that we are currently not present in. Regarding the linearity of ADS-B, of course, we're seeing accelerating growth in that area as people become more aware of, and interested in complying with the mandate. And we would expect to see stronger growth in ADS-B as we move into 2017 and 2018.

headline: Garmin Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: We have a follow-up question from the line of Joe Wittine with Longbow Research.

componenttext: In Automotive, can you give any sense of what the OEM business looks like on an organic or apples-to-apples basis in light vehicles to exclude the impact of deferreds?

componenttext: Yes. So from Auto OEM business, yes, excluding deferred, basically we did see some improvement there on a cash basis, year-over-year.

componenttext: Okay. Is the -- an improvement -- so you are growing year-over-year or the rate of growth is improving, or both?

componenttext: Yes, we are improving, yes. Dollars.

componenttext: Okay, got it.  Then maybe just finally, Doug, tax rate question. What's a good place to land our '17 model, given you've changed the '16 number here, given the change in Swiss tax laws we're all monitoring as well?

componenttext: Yes, so we'll actually give guidance on '17 in February. So it's a little too early for that at this point in time. We'll go through the filing [ph] process over the next few months.
